title: Eukaryotic Cell Structure
description: Discover the complex internal structure of eukaryotic cells. Learn about organelles, their functions, and how they work together to keep cells alive.
learningIntentions: Identify and describe major eukaryotic organelles
Explain the function of each organelle

syllabusLinks.module: Module 1: Cells as the Basis of Life
syllabusLinks.inquiryQuestion: What distinguishes one cell from another?

successCriteria: Label an animal and plant cell correctly
Explain three differences between plant and animal cells

engagementHook.title: Cell City Analogy
engagementHook.content: Imagine a cell as a city. The nucleus is like city hall (control center), mitochondria are power plants, and the cell membrane is like the city border. Just as a city needs all these parts working together, a cell needs its organelles to function!

contentSections.title: What are Eukaryotes?
contentSections.content:
Eukaryotes are organisms whose cells contain a membrane-bound nucleus and other membrane-bound organelles. The word comes from Greek: 'eu' meaning true, and 'karyon' meaning nut or kernel.

Eukaryotes include animals, plants, fungi, and protists. They can be unicellular (like yeast or amoeba) or multicellular (like humans or trees).

contentSections.title: The Nucleus
contentSections.definition: The control center of the cell containing genetic material (DNA) organized into chromosomes. It is surrounded by a double membrane called the nuclear envelope.

contentSections.title: Plant vs Animal Cells
contentSections.content: While plant and animal cells are both eukaryotic, they have important differences:
items: Plant cells have a cell wall; animal cells do not
Plant cells have chloroplasts for photosynthesis; animals do not
Plant cells have a large central vacuole; animals have small vacuoles
Animal cells have centrioles; most plant cells do not
Plant cells are generally more rectangular; animal cells are more irregular

activities.title: Activity 1: Match Organelle to Function
activities.description: Match each organelle with its primary function:

activities.title: Activity 2: Plant vs Animal
activities.description: Fill in the blanks with 'Plant' or 'Animal':

definitions: Eukaryote: An organism with cells containing a membrane-bound nucleus and organelles
Nucleus: The control center containing DNA, surrounded by a nuclear envelope
Mitochondria: Organelles that produce ATP through cellular respiration
Chloroplast: Organelle in plant cells where photosynthesis occurs
keyPoints: Eukaryotic cells have a nucleus and membrane-bound organelles
Major organelles: nucleus, mitochondria, ribosomes, ER, Golgi, lysosomes, vacuoles
Plant cells have: cell walls, chloroplasts, large central vacuoles
Animal cells have: centrioles, lack cell walls and chloroplasts

multipleChoice.question: Which organelle is responsible for protein synthesis?
Which structure is found in plant cells but NOT in animal cells?
What is the function of the Golgi apparatus?

shortAnswer.question: Describe the structure and function of mitochondria.
Explain three differences between plant and animal cells.

multipleChoice: C - Chloroplasts are only in plant cells
C - Golgi modifies and packages proteins
shortAnswer: Mitochondria are double-membraned organelles with folded inner membrane (cristae). They are the site of cellular respiration and produce ATP for the cell.
Plant cells have cell walls, chloroplasts, and large central vacuoles. Animal cells have centrioles and lack the plant-specific structures.
